summary: "Of Mice and Men" is a short novel by John Steinbeck, published in 1937. It tells the story of George and Lennie, two friends who work as migrant ranch workers in California during the Great Depression. Steinbeck based this on his own experiences working with farm workers. The title comes from a poem by Robert Burns, meaning that even the best plans can fail. The book is popular in schools, but has also faced censorship due to its language. It's one of the most challenged books in the 21st century in the U.S.
title: Of Mice and Men
